summary: studies indicate that RSV infection is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates in children with acute lower respiratory infections (ALRIs) in both industrialized and developing countries [1–4]. Approximately 34 million RSV-related ALRIs occur in children under 5 years of age, resulting in at least 3.4 million hospitalizations and 66,000–199,000 RSV-related deaths. study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (China CDC, Beijing, China) subjects with laboratory confirmed RSV infection were hospitalized at 12 sentinel hospitals located in 6 provinces in eastern china between January 2009 and December 2013. patient enrollment, sample collection, laboratory testing, and case reporting were conducted by all sentinel hospitals and laboratories according to a national surveillance protocol. all specimens were tested for RSV (A and B subtypes), human influenza virus, human parainfluenza virus (HPIV), human parainfluenza virus (HPIV), human bocavirus (HBoV), adenovirus (AdV), rhinovirus (RV), coronavirus (CoV), human metapneumovirus (HMPV) and enterovirus (EV) by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR), reverse transcriptase all sentinel hospitals and laboratories according to a national surveillance protocol [17]. patients were admitted to surveillance wards presided over by the departments of pediatrics, internal medicine, and infectious diseases or to the intensive care units of the abovementioned sentinel hospitals. they were screened by physicians and nurses for ALRI. descriptive statistics were used to analyze demographic, epidemiological and clinical characteristics of the patients with RSV infection. 154 (14.7%) were diagnosed with RSV-A, 253 (24.2%) were diagnosed with RSV-B, 249 (23.8%) were subtyping not performed, and 390 (37.3%) were diagnosed with coinfections with RSV and other respiratory tract viruses. a total of 12 sentinel hospitals located in six provinces were enrolled in the final RSV infection analysis. a total of 12 sentinel hospitals located in six provinces were enrolled in the final analysis. the median age of patients with RSV single-infections (8–12 months) was considerably lower than that of patients with coinfections (24 months) the median age of patients with RSV single-infections (8–12 months) was considerably lower than that of patients with coinfections (24 months) the majority of RSV infections occurred between September 2010 and February 2011. RSV-A infections were most frequently observed between January and April in 2009, 2010 and 2013. temperature of 38°C was documented in 61.0% of patients with RSV infection. 59.0% of patients with RSV coinfection with other viruses at time of physical examination. significant differences between patients with RSV coinfections and patients with RSV single-infections were observed. of the patients with pneumonia/RSV coinfection was not significantly different from that of patients with laboratory-confirmed RSV single-infection (2 = 0.653, P = 0.419) Table 2. RSV infection was more common in young children aged 5 years (89.1%, 932/1046) than in patients aged 5 years (11.9%, 114/1046) median age of patients with RSV single-infections (8–12 months) was considerably lower than that of patients with coinfections (24 months) median age of patients with RSV single-infections (8–12 months) was considerably lower than that of patients with coinfections (24 months) 28 (7.2%) 5 y 29 (2.8%) 1 (0.6%) 4 (1.6%) 7 (2.8%) 17 (4.4%) 6–9 y 66 (6.3%) 3 (1.9%) 13 (5.1%) 12 (4.8%) 36 (9.2%) 10–14 y 16 (1.5%) 2 (1.3%) 1 (0.4%) 7 (2.8%) 7 (1.8%) 15–59 y 20 (1.9%) 10 (6.5%) 1 (0.4%) 5 (2.0%) 5 (1.3%) 60 y 12 (1.1%) 7 ( Cough was the most common symptom exhibited by RSV patients (66.3%), and runny nose (22.7%) and sputum production (18.6%) were also common among affected patients. significant differences between patients with RSV coinfections with other viruses and patients with RSV single-infections were observed. 113 (59.4%) 117 (55.4%) Cough 694 (66.3%) 124 (80.5%) 215 (85.0%) 114 (45.8%) 103 (54.2%) 138 (69%) Runny nose 237 (22.7%) 52(33.8%) 73 (28.9%) 43 (17.3%) 32 (16.8%) 37 (18.5%) Sore throat 93 (8.9%) 11 (7.1%) 3 (1.2%) 30 (12.0%) 35 (18.4%) 14 (7%) 4.0 17 (3.7%) 1 (1.4%) 12 (6.9%) 1 (2.4%) 1 (1.1%) 3 (3.9%) >10.0 173 (38.2%) 27 (39.1%) 52 (29.7%) 22 (53.7%) 40 (44.0%) 32 (41.6%) L(%) 43 (27–58) 48 (33–58) 50 (36–64) 32(19–52) 32 (20–53) 32 (20–53) 42 (26–54) 20% 71 (15.7%) 5 ( 8 (19.5%) 28 (30.8%) 24 (31.2%) >150 13 (2.9%) 5 (7.2%) 2 (1.1%) 3 (7.3%) 2 (2.2%) 1 (1.3%) Blood gas analysis (cases) 104 24 21 8 10 41 pH 7.38 (7.34–7.41) 7.36 (7.33–7.4) 7.37 (7.34–7.4) 7.41 (7.39–7.45) 7.37 (7.33–7.39) 7.38 (7.34–7.42) 7.35 of 147 patients with RSV infection, 102 were treated with one drug. Amoxicillin-clavulanate (23.5%, 24/102) was the most frequently prescribed antibacterial drug. Cefuroxime (17.6, 18/102) was the second most frequently prescribed antibacterial drug. from 2009 to 2013, a total of 1046 hospitalized ALRI patients (children and adults) were treated at 12 sentinel hospitals in eastern china. we found that most patients had RSV single-infections and 37.3% had mixed viral infections caused by RSV and influenza. children aged 5 years represented the largest proportion of patients with RSV infections (86.4%) and coinfections (83.3%), particularly young children (total: 62.3%; coinfections: 48.7%) aged 2 years, compared to patients aged 5 years. findings indicate that an association exists between RSV prevalence and age. the proportions of patients with pneumonia were not significantly different between patients with RSV coinfection and patients with RSV single-infections. however, the proportions of patients with pneumonia were not significantly different between patients with RSV coinfection and patients with RSV single-infections. only a few patients with RSV infections were treated with broad-spectrum antiviral drugs. study provided important epidemiologic information regarding RSV and associated respiratory viral infections in patients with ALRIs in eastern china. timely and accurate diagnosis of RSV infection in patients with ALRIs is necessary to prevent large-scale RSV spread.
